awd_titl_txt: CPS: Large: Cybernetic Interfaces for the Restoration of Human Movement through Functional Electrical Stimulation
awd_abstract_narration:
CPS: Large: Cybernetic interfaces for the restoration of human movement through functional electrical stimulation

The objective of this research is to develop an intuitive user interface for functional electrical stimulation (FES), which uses surgically-implanted electrodes to stimulate muscles in spinal cord-injured (SCI) patients.  The challenge is to enable high-level tetraplegic patients to regain the use of their own arm.  The approach is to develop a multi-modal Bayesian user-intent decoder; use natural muscle synergies to generate appropriate low-dimensional muscle activation signals in a feedforward controller; develop a feedback controller to enhance the performance of the feedforward controller; and test the system with SCI patients on daily living tasks, such as reaching, grasping, and eating.
The challenge problem of restoring arm use to SCI patients will lead to new design principles for cyber-physical systems interfacing neural and biological systems with engineered computation and electrical power systems.  The tight integration of the proposed user interface and controller with the users own control system requires a deep understanding of biological design principles such as nested feedback loops at different time and length scales, noisy signals, parallel processing, and highly coupled neuromechanical systems.
This work will lead to new technology that dramatically improves the lives of spinal cord-injured patients.  These patients often have no cognitive impairment and have long life spans after injury.  The goal is to enable these patients to eat, reach, and grasp nearby objects.  These tasks are critical for independent living and quality of life.  This work will also help train a new generation of students in human-machine interfaces at the undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral levels.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project was to develop a system that could be used to restore reaching control to subjects with high-level spinal cord injury. Such subjects are typically paralyzed below the level of the neck.  In our project, we used implanted electrical stimulators, similar to pacemakers, to activate paralyzed muscles in the arm thereby providing a means to control movement.  The main challenges were determining how the subject wished to use her arm, and then deciding on how to electrically activate her muscles so as to realize those wishes.  

The first challenge is known as the decoding problem. It was solved by recording eye movements and activity from muscles in the neck and shoulder. We developed an algorithm that could use these biological signals to infer each subjects intended movements.  

The second challenge is known as a system identification and control problem. For this we first needed to determine a mathematical representation between the electrical commands the implanted stimulator, and the resulting motions and forces of the subject's arm. This process is known as system identification. Once this relationship was established, we were able to design and implement a control system to generate the subject's desired movements and also to exert specific forces on objects in the environment.

While our project had the specific objective of restoring movement to paralyzed individuals, the technologies we developed are broadly applicable. The decoding algorithm was purposefully designed to work with a wide variety of signals relevant to human-machine interfaces.  Examples include voluntary movements, forces, position of the eyes, or even thoughts recorded directly from the brain. Our system identification and algorithms are particularly useful for the modeling and control of complex systems that cannot easily be described by analytical equations.  These include the human body, as was relevant to our specific application, but also other complex systems including environmental control or potentially even social dynamics.

In addition to the scientific and engineering outcomes, our project included a major outreach component designed to foster creativity and talent in junior high students. Our program, Project CARE (Cyber-physical Applications for Rehabilitation and Education), was designed to enhance educational outcomes in science, math, technology and communication.  This is accomplished through a guided, challenge-based curriculum focused on cyber-physical systems. Our first learning module focuses on rehabilitation, providing a concrete demonstration of how cyber-physical systems can have a positive impact on society.  The next modules provide in-depth exploration of computer programming and mechatronic systems. Approximately 40-50 children in grades 7-8 participate each year.
